Story: The Greatest Show in the Galaxy

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Ringmaster enters to the cheers of the crowd, and cracks his whip. Then he does a quick tap dance and starts his rap.

Dialogue.Line: Now welcome folks, I'm sure you'd like to know, we're at the start of one big circus show. There are acts that are cool and acts that amaze. Some acts are scary and some acts will daze. Acts of all kinds, you can count on that, from folks that fly to disappearing acts. There are lots of surprises for the family at the Greatest Show in the Galaxy! So many strange surprises, I'm prepared to bet, whatever you've seen before, you ain't seen nothing yet.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor is practising juggling with three cricket balls and the aid of a book called Juggling for the Complete Klutz.

Dialogue.Line: Professor?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Some clothes get thrown through the interior door.

Dialogue.Line: Yes?
Have you seen my Nitro Nine?
Isn't it in your rucksack?
Yeah, but where's my rucksack?
Interesting question.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Ace emerges on her hands and knees with a long scarf around her neck.

Dialogue.Line: Things don't just vanish.
No.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: One of the three balls up and doesn't come down again.

A landing platform by a large billboard advertising the Psychic Circus - The Greatest Show in the Galaxy - starts spouting smoke, then a three wheeled motorcycle appears, ridden by a man with very large wings on his helmet. He drives it off the ramp then opens a side pod and takes out a hot burger in a bun, then bites into it with relish.
A curious six legged gizmo with two small solar panels and an antenna on its head appears. The Doctor is on a step ladder hunting for his ball in the console room ceiling.

Dialogue.Line: What's that peculiar noise?
What peculiar noise? I don't hear any peculiar.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: They notice the gizmo.

Dialogue.Line: How extraordinary.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: He comes down the ladder.

Dialogue.Line: It materialised inside the Tardis. Just the kind of thing you'd expect to see in this part of the galaxy.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The gizmo trundles across the floor to the console.

Dialogue.Line: Is that just what you'd expect too, Professor?
Not entirely, no.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The gizmo then slaps a lead onto the console and the scanner starts up with an advertisement.

Dialogue.Line: Yes, it's festival time at the Psychic Circus, the Greatest Show in the Galaxy! So why not come along and have the time of your life with the nonstop action of its glittering circus ring. There's big prizes
No, I don't believe it. Junk mail. Used to get loads of this stuff through the letterbox and now we're being bombarded with it inside the Tardis.
Yes, junk mail gets everywhere.
If you want to watch or you want to compete, there's a great time for you on the planet Segonax. The planet has easy access via our special polyportable landing bays.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Ace disconnects the gizmo.

Dialogue.Line: Oh, Ace, I thought you'd have been interested in the circus.
No, kid's stuff. I went once. Didn't even have any tigers. It was naff and it was boring. Apart from the clowns, of course.
What, you found them funny?
No, creepy.

I think you're being very unfair. A lot of the acts in the circus require a great deal of skill and courage. That's something you should appreciate. Anyway, I rather fancy entering the Festival talent contest myself.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: And starts to play a pair of salad spoons on his leg.

Dialogue.Line: Oh no, not the spoons again.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The gizmo reattaches itself.

Dialogue.Line: Scared?
What?
Scared to come to the Psychic Circus?
No.
Scared to take part?
No, course not.
Well, if you are, then go ahead, ignore me. I quite understand.
I don't believe it. Junk mail that talks back.
Shall we just fling it away and forget about it? I mean, I'm sure the Psychic Circus isn't scary at all. It's just a device to get us to go.
Okay, you win, junk box. I'm not scared of anything.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A young man and a girl run across the rough, dry ground. He falls. He is wearing a yellow jacket with lots of frogging on it, while she is in a lacy floral dress.

Dialogue.Line: Come on, we can't give up now.
They'll catch us, I know it. They'll drag us back to the circus.
Oh, Bellboy, please. You promised. You know it's down to us now. We're the only ones left to fight. Come on.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A Bentley hearse cruises along the skyline. It stops and the passenger window winds down to reveal a white-faced clown in undertakers clothing. He gets out and looks up at a pair of kites in the sky, flying without the aid of strings. His companion adjusts a control in the car and the kites swoop away. They follow. Meanwhile, Bellboy and the Flowerchild arrive at the dunes. The kites fly overhead.

Dialogue.Line: Flowerchild, look. Your kites, your beautiful kites.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Tardis materialises on the rocky shore. The Doctor and Ace come out.

Dialogue.Line: So this is Segonax. Not quite the green and pleasant land we'd been led to expect. Still, I've had good reports of the friendliness of the natives.
Don't see these landing bays, Professor.
Oh, I expect that's for those not fortunate enough to possess a Tardis.
So now where?
I'll ask for directions over there.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: They head for a snack stall in the middle of nowhere as the tricycle rider drives along a dusty track, throwing the remains of his burger over his shoulder.

Dialogue.Line: Good afternoon. I'm the Doctor, this is my friend Ace.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The lady stallholder looks up from peeling a turnip. Everyone say Hi! to the formidable  Peggy Mount.

Dialogue.Line: What sort of costume do you call that?
I don't understand.
And her's is no better. We don't want your type around here.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: She pushes between Ace and the Doctor. His hand goes into something gunky on the stall, possibly the Plaup from Vulpana at 30 epsy.

Dialogue.Line: Ah, and what type might that be?
Wierdos. You can tell them at a glance, you know.
Friendly natives, eh, Professor?
Let's not be hasty.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Stallholder uses a sharp cleaver to chop a melon.

Dialogue.Line: There's no choice.
No. The kites will track us forever.
One of us must get there.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: She kisses him, then takes off a large circular earring.

Dialogue.Line: I want you to have this.
Thanks. Look, I'll wait here awhile and see if I can find a longer route round. I shall draw them after me.
No silly risks, now.
Go on. Go on.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The kites hang motionless. The clown gets out of the hearse.

Dialogue.Line: They can't have lost them.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The kites move.

Dialogue.Line: I thought not.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Meanwhile -

Dialogue.Line: Come on, kites. Find me.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Ace is digging her fingers into the soft innards of a large fruit.

Dialogue.Line: Yuck. Do we really have to eat this muck?

Elementary diplomacy, my dear Ace. She apparently thinks we're a pair of undesirable intergalactic hippies. We must try and convince her we're nice, clean-living people who eat up all our fresh fruit and pay our way.
Paying good money for this muck is daylight robbery. Do I have to finish it?
Every last bite. Besides, we want the charming lady to tell us how to find the circus, don't we. Delicious, madam. Quite delicious.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Bellboy shouts up at the kites.

Dialogue.Line: Come on, then! It's me, Bellboy. It's who you're looking for, isn't it? What are you waiting for? Come on!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Flowerchild has got to a painted bus with a picture of Bellboy on it and the slogan The Road is Open and the Rides are Free on it. Also Give Some Money. She goes inside.

Dialogue.Line: More?

Er, no. Delicious but extremely filling. I'm sure you will have gathered by now, dear lady, we're not the kind of hobbledyhoys and vagabonds you take such exception to. Indeed, as I said before, I'm known as the Doctor.
Some people will call themselves anything.
Yes, well, be that as it may, we would appreciate your help. You see, we're looking for

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The noise of the tricycle cuts the air as it drives down the track.

Dialogue.Line: Here comes another one of your lot.
Look at that ace bike, Professor.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The bike pulls up in a series of backfires, and Ace runs over.

Dialogue.Line: Need a hand? I reckon it could be a stuck valve.
Get lost.
It's a great bike.
Go on, hop it, before I get angry.
Well, if you don't want to save yourself some time, then it's up to you. Course, it could be a valve
I've told you, girl, get lost! Or I'll do something horrible to your ears.
Suit yourself. I hope your big end goes.
He'll be going there. They all go there, you know.
Go where?
The Psychic Circus. All the riff-raff go there. All the infernal extraterrestrials like him. Monopods from Lelex, Doctors.
I don't understand. You say that he's going to the circus?
Of course. Everyone of them who's up to no good goes there. We locals wouldn't touch it with a barge pole.
Is it far, this appalling spectacle?
Miles and miles. Why do you suppose he's got that noisy monstrosity polluting the countryside? Here, you're not thinking of going there, are you?
No, no, the very idea, no. Just a moment, would you excuse me?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor goes over to Ace and Nord.

Dialogue.Line: Ace, any chance of a lift, do you think?
Worth a try, I suppose. He doesn't look after that bike, you know. If only he'd let me have a go,
Yes, yes, never mind, Ace. Let's concentrate on getting a lift to the circus. Excuse me. If you're going to the circus, I wonder if could possibly give
Do you want me to do something unpleasant to your face?
No, not really, no.
No one rides with me! For I am Nord, Vandal of the roads.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Flowerchild gets off the bus carrying a cash box, and tries to open it. A dark clothed figures follows her out and grabs her round the throat.

Dialogue.Line: Hold tight please.
Well, there's nothing like a nice walk in the countryside.
And this is nothing like a nice walk in the countryside.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The hearse comes down the track towards them.

Dialogue.Line: Now, now, now, it could be worse. You could be carrying that heavy rucksack of yours.
Yeah, what about my rucksack, Professor? What did you do with it?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The hearse sounds its horn and the Doctor pushes Ace out of the way as it drives straight between them without slowing.

Dialogue.Line: They seem to be in rather a hurry. Looking for customers.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Further on.

Dialogue.Line: Well, I wouldn't be so chuffed if I kept getting visitors like Nord the Vandal, I suppose.
That's true. But then, how do they expect a hard case like him to going to the circus anyway?
Maybe he got conned, like I was.
Something evil's happened here, I can feel it.
To do with the circus?
Who knows.
Doctor, look.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Ace points over the ridge to a campsite.
A silver haired man in khaki and wearing a solar topi is surveying the landscape with binoculars. His young female companion has green hair and is examining a metal arm sticking out of the sand.

Dialogue.Line: I was probably the first person to visit the valley for several millennia, at the very least. So something like this, which for the ordinary dull old stop-at-home might seem quite extraordinary, is just run of the mill as far as I'm concerned. Well, of course since you've never been
Captain.
Greetings. I'm the Doctor and this is my friend Ace.
And I am Captain Cook, the eminent intergalactic explorer. You happen to have heard of me, old boy?
And I am Mags.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Ace touches the arm and the hand snaps shut.
A clown is balancing one-footed on a wire when Nord drives up.

Dialogue.Line: Oi, white-face. White-face! Where do I park for the gig at the Psychic Circus?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The clown wobbles and sort of gestures thataway, so Nord drives towards the Big Top. A large ringed moon hangs in the daylight sky.
Mags pours tea for the Captain and the Doctor. The Captain has a china cup, the Doctor has a tin mug.

Dialogue.Line: Mmm, delicious. My own special blend, of course. I take it everywhere. Bet you can't guess the blend, eh, Doctor?
Well, I could be wrong, of course, but isn't it from the Groz Valley of Melogothon?
Good. Very good.
(to Mags) I'll give you a hand.
Oh, Ace, wait a minute.
Were you ever on Melogothon, Doctor?
Well as a matter of fact, I was.
The frozen pits of Overod are worth seeing, of course, though much overrated, I feel. All right for the trainee explorer. Old hands like myself need something a bit more exotic.
Why come here, then?
Sorry, old boy?
I said, why bother to come here?
Well, I'm told the Psychic Circus is quite an interesting little show, particularly at this time, when everybody turns up to compete in the Festival. Yes, besides, she wanted to come.
Do you often travel together?
Of late, yes. I found her on the planet Vulpana. Between you and me, old boy, she's rather an unusual little specimen.
Of what?
Ah, that would be telling, old boy. What about yours?
I never think of Ace as a specimen of anything.
Keep your shirt on, Doctor. Everything's a specimen of something. Take that robot over there, for example.
What do you reckon, Professor?
I suppose it was buried for some good reason.
Well, maybe we'll find out what that reason was, eh, Professor?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The now uncovered robot suddenly tilts upright, knocking Mags over and grabbing her leg.

Dialogue.Line: Gordon Bennett!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Laser's shoot from its eyes, hitting the camp stool and sending the Doctor tumbling. He rushes to help free Mags.

Dialogue.Line: Quick. Help, Captain.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Captain keeps sipping his tea.

Dialogue.Line: You don't often see one like that, do you.
I've seen ones like this quite often enough, thank you very much.
Do something! I've got it.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Ace picks up a shovel and hits the robot's head. It stops. The Doctor helps Mags get out of range.

Dialogue.Line: Well, well. More tea, perhaps?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: There is a new arrival - a geeky lad in round glasses on a mountain bike, at the landing bay. Meanwhile the Conductor drags Flowerchild's body away, leaving behind her other earring. The hearse follows the kites.
Bellboy staggers up.

Dialogue.Line: Excuse me.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: And falls down.

Dialogue.Line: You can't lie down there, you know.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The hearse pulls up.

Dialogue.Line: At last.
Where's the girl?
She'll have reached there by now.
If she has, she'll regret it.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The clown and his companion drag the Bellboy away.

Dialogue.Line: Is there no end to you wierdos?
It's obviously some sort of shrine. I saw one much like this on Dioscuros.
A shrine or not, I can't help feeling something sinister happened here.
I wonder you manage to explore anything. Everything seems to alarm you so.
Not everything. I trust my instincts, and you may recall they're not always wrong.
Oh, come on, Professor. Let's go and explore.
I agree with your young friend. Let's explore.
Here, look at this.
I say. Well, well, well, it is quite something.
Wonder if it still goes.
Yes.
Ace, I wouldn't.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: As Ace settles herself behind the steering wheel, the robot conductor comes through a curtain towards the back of the bus.

Dialogue.Line: Any more fares, please? Any more fares, please? No standing inside. Hold tight, please.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Conductor turns the handle of its ticket machine, and an energy bolt zooms up to the sun roof.

Dialogue.Line: I say, steady on, old chap.
Fares please. Hold on tight. Ding, ding.
No, no, no, you've got it wrong, old boy. He's paying the fares, not me.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Captain disembarks rapidly.

Dialogue.Line: Any more fares?

I would like a ticket, actually. I'd like a there and back off peak weekend break supersaver senior citizen bimonthly season with optional added facilities a free cup of coffee in a plastic glass a crocodile sandwich and make it snappy, you mechanic moron!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The robot drops its head.

Dialogue.Line: If I might take a look at that ticket machine of yours?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The robot holds it up.

Dialogue.Line: Ah, yes.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor turns the handle and zaps the robot. Bang!

Dialogue.Line: Just the ticket.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Ticket office is strictly speaking a small caravan inside a tent housing various advertising boards of the Circus's trip to various planets. It is linked to the Big Top by a corridor with walls of billowing cloth. The clowns drop Bellboy at the Fortune Teller's feet.

Dialogue.Line: What have you done?
Not nearly enough.
We need him.
He'll have to be punished, Morgana.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Clown removes his black clothes to reveal his silver costume.

Dialogue.Line: Flowerchild?
No.
Flowerchild.
Where is she?
He still thinks she may have escaped.
Listen, Bellboy, I
Save your breath. Take him back in the ring. He knows what's waiting there.
No. No. No! No! No!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Bellboy is dragged away by clowns.

Dialogue.Line: What if a visitor arrives now?
If they come, they come.
Letrepos, for example. Sights like this are every day.
Some people can't bear to be proved wrong.
He'd have let tinhead do you in.
Oh, let's not bear a grudge. He can't help being a pompous, selfish, self-satisfied meddler.
Hmm. Mags might be okay if he wasn't around.
If a little odd.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Ace finds Flowerchild's earring.

Dialogue.Line: Doctor, look.
Do you like it?
Yeah.
Well, if the keeper's not here, the finder has it.
Ace.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: She pins it onto her jacket.

Dialogue.Line: What do you reckon happened here, Professor? Were the people in this bus attacked on their way to the circus?
Presumably. Whoever attacked them, destroyed them and wrecked the bus.
And the evil you felt, was that the bus conductor?
Yes, I think so. Anyway, whoever left him here on guard's gone now. Perhaps millennia ago.
Nothing to do with the circus being scary?
I'm afraid I think not. No, that was all just good publicity.
Pity. It might have made it more interesting. Are we still going there then?
Yes. I feel just in the right mood. And after two brushes with death in one day, I hope you might be.
If you say so, Doctor.
Ah, so, Doctor. You can remember.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Captain's jeep drives past a man on stilts.

Dialogue.Line: On one of my trips to Neogorgon there was a whole planet with electronic dogs' heads submerged in mud.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The geek on the bike pedals up.

Dialogue.Line: Hi!
Hello, young man. Just arrived from the landing port?
That's right.
Oh, you've no idea what a relief for me it is to see such a nice, clean, respectable young man, after the riff-raff I usually have to deal with. Can I help you at all?
Yes, please. Could you tell me the way to the Psychic Circus?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Stallholder's smile fades away.

Dialogue.Line: The show is about to start.
I've seen enough already.
Greetings, my good woman. This is the Psychic Circus, isn't it?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Morgana puts on a Transylvanian accent.

Dialogue.Line: Why yes, that's right.
Ah, sounds like things are going well. Come along, Mags.
But er
But what?
You can't go in just now. There is a speciality act being rehearsed.
All the better, my dear.
No, you don't understand.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Clown appears, laughs, and gestures for the Captain and Mags to enter.

Dialogue.Line: Thank you, my good fellow. Thank you.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The clown comes out and waves to the Doctor and Ace, then goes back inside.

Dialogue.Line: Two more.
Right.
I did hear it, that screaming.
But not now.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Ace shakes her head.

Dialogue.Line: So we can go in?
Yeah, okay.
Your enthusiasm's overwhelming.
Welcome one and all to the Psychic Circus.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Ace turns to leave but the Doctor pulls her back.

Dialogue.Line: Ace, you promised. (to Morgana) I'm the Doctor and this is Ace. I must apologise for my young friend.
Oh, it is no problem. All of us around here believe in letting our feelings hang out. I mean, there is no point in getting uptight, now is there?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Ace sees the clown watching and becomes tense.

Dialogue.Line: I don't believe this.
That is why we got into circuses in the first place.
We?
The founder members of the Psychic Circus.
Ah, I see.
We were really into personal expression and the Circus gave us a chance to develop ourselves by expressing our individual skills.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor sees three kites with eyes painted on them.

Dialogue.Line: I wonder if you've a special skill, if I might enquire.
Fortune telling. Would you like to see the future?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Morgana turns over the top card on her Tarot pack. It is the Hanged Man, symbol of major change. The Doctor does not turn round to look at it.

Dialogue.Line: Not just yet.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The funeral clowns carry the robot bus conductor backstage on a stretcher.

Dialogue.Line: The Psychic Circus has grown into quite a sizeable operation, by the looks of it.
The greatest show in the galaxy.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor looks around their collection of advertising posters.

Dialogue.Line: Quite so, yes. My, you have travelled, haven't you? The planet Othris, the Boriatic Wastes, Marpesia and the Grand Pagoda of Cinethon.
Yes, we used to have a great time in the old days, going from planet to planet. But we've really got settled in here since
Since?
Well, you have to hang up your travelling shoes and stop wandering sooner or later, don't you?
So I've been told. Personally, I just keep on wandering.
Will you please take your seats, thank you.
Ace?
Yes, Professor?
Well, are we going in or aren't we?
You're sure you want to go in?
Yes, that's why we came here in the first place.
Look, I don't know how to put this, but

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The clown comes out.

Dialogue.Line: Of course, go right in. Do your own thing. Enjoy yourselves.
Thank you. Oh, tickets. We forgot to buy some tickets.
Tickets?
To go in.
Ha ha! You're in already.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Noises of a massive crowd cheering.

Dialogue.Line: Oh. Sounds as if you're doing really good business.
This way, please.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The clown sees Flowerchild's earring on Ace's jacket as she passes him.
It is dark and quiet as the Doctor and Ace enter. They whisper to each other.

Dialogue.Line: Professor.
Yes?
I can't see a thing.
Neither can I.
And the cheering's stopped.
Perhaps we're between performances. Let's see if we can find a seat.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor feels his way to the stands and climbs the steps. He stubs his toe.

Dialogue.Line: Found somewhere to sit, Professor?
That's one way of looking at it, if we could see. Over here.
What?
I said, over here.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: They settle down.

Dialogue.Line: In a moment our eyes'll get used to the darkness.
Assuming there's anything worth seeing.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: There is a rustling noise nearby.

Dialogue.Line: Listen.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: On the row above them sits a 1950's family, Father, Mother and a little girl between them. They are eating a noisy snack.

Dialogue.Line: Daddy. Daddy.
What?
I want an ice cream.
You've already had one.
But Daddy.
I told you once and I'm not going to tell you again. Now shut up and eat your popcorn.
We're not alone.
Yeah, but it looks like it's just us and them. What a con. I mean, where's Mags and the Captain?
Perhaps they haven't arrived yet. Who knows? Anyway, I'm going to have an ice cream.
They should be starting up again soon. Have a crisp, Father.
Greetings. Not many in today, are there. Are you regulars or is this your first visit, too? Let me introduce myself. I'm

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Mother holds out the bag of crisps.

Dialogue.Line: Oh, thank you very much. Delicious.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The circus music starts and the lights come up.

Dialogue.Line: Professor. Professor, it's starting.
Well, it's been a pleasure.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor returns to sit with Ace as the ring fills with tumbling and juggling clowns.

Dialogue.Line: Remarkable.
If you like this sort of thing.
No, no, I mean the memorial stones. Do you see them? Look.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Placed at intervals around the ring are old carved stones. The Ringmaster enters and the clowns freeze.

Dialogue.Line: Now welcome folks, I mean that from the heart, because the Greatest Show is about to start. It's happening right here before your very eyes and one thing's for sure, you're in for quite a surprise. But then, nothing's quite as it seems to be at the Greatest Show in the Galaxy.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Ringmaster adjusts the controls in the back of one clown and it does a somersault.

Dialogue.Line: Now welcome folks, we've got a brand new act. He's a real find and no doubt that's a fact. He'll entertain you, he'll make you stare, and our great new act is seated over there!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The spotlight falls on the Doctor.

Dialogue.Line: Oh, thank you, but
Come on, Doctor. Don't be shy.
Well, I'm not really sure that I should.
Oh, no false modesty. We know you're good.
Well, this is most unexpected. Are you sure you want me?
There's no mistake, Doc. Come on in. Feel free.
Don't go, Professor.
Why, what harm could it do?
Exactly. But the decision's up to you.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Wearing a big grin, the Doctor pushes past Ace and hurries down the ring, to canned applause.

Dialogue.Line: No, Doctor!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor has barely got into the ring when the clowns start throwing their clubs past him, front and back.

Dialogue.Line: Well, you certainly didn't waste any time. I had expected to see what the opposition was up to before I put myself forward for the talent contest.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Ace tries to run out of the Big Top but is surrounded by clowns behind the seating where the Doctor cannot see.

Dialogue.Line: But since you insist.
Oh, we do, but no doubt you'd like to get yourself prepared first.
Well, yes, I
Let me show you and your charming assistant to your dressing room.
Oh, thank you very much. Ace!
Where did you find that earring?
Are you a robot too?
No.
Pity.
So tell me where you found it.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Ace gets away.

Dialogue.Line: After her.
Right this way, Doctor.
Thank you very much, but where's Ace? I don't think she
Oh, she'll be coming.
Iniphitus, where the Galvanic Catastrophods are not what they were.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor looks through to where the Captain is drinking tea and talking at a bored Nord while Mags is staring at nothing.

Dialogue.Line: No, but they're still worth a look if you're doing a tour of the southern nebula and have an eon or two to spare. You. Well, well.
Captain Cook, I presume. So you had arrived after all.
But of course. Come and join us, Doctor. It's one big happy family here, eh, Nord?
Except when you're gassing on.
Well, I don't really think I
Nonsense, we're having a ball here.
Very well then. Mags. Do sit down, Doctor.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Mags give up her seat next to the Captain and pours out some tea.

Dialogue.Line: Thank you very much.
Yes, there we are. Comfy?
Yes.
That's the spirit.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Bars slide down over the entrance, then the curtains are all pulled back to reveal that the quartet are actually in a -

Dialogue.Line: Anything the matter, old chap?
It's a trap! I've fallen into a trap! I've fallen for it.
Yes, I know, old boy. Never mind. Have some tea. A very similar thing happened to me once, you know.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Ace uses the pin of the earring to slash the billowing fabric of the backstage corridors and hide from the pursuing clowns.

Dialogue.Line: Why?
Why what?
Why let me be trapped? It's so pointless. I could have saved you, Nord and Mags.
I wouldn't be too sure about that, Doctor. These circus chappies are pretty smart customers for all their let it all hang out mumbo jumbo.
Maybe we could have escaped if we'd made a break for it there and then. If only you'd
Now, now, Mags. No use in getting upset, and that's an order.
What about you? I mean, why didn't you speak up?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Nord growls. The Doctor growls back.

Dialogue.Line: What kind of answer's that?
Save your energy, Doctor. You'll soon see why. Anyway, all of us in here have developed a survival philosophy, which is why we welcomed you in.
What is all this, then? I thought there was a talent contest going on.
Well, yes, but in a way it's more like a survival of the fittest.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A man in a suede jacket pushes a broom round the outside of the cage.

Dialogue.Line: Oh, that's Deadbeat. Yes, he does odd jobs about the place, makes the tea for me, things like that. Don't bother too much about him, though. Fellow's mind's completely gone.
Gone. Gone. Oh really gone. All really gone down the road again.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Ace sneaks out and hides behind the kites while Morgana lays out Tarot cards. The Ringmaster comes up to her.

Dialogue.Line: Well?
We have to talk.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Nord tries to grab the chuckling Deadbeat.

Dialogue.Line: Get out of it! I hate your sort, cos I'm Nord, see? The toughest infernal extraterrestrial there is.
What a fool I've been.
Frankly, old chap, I have to agree.
I should have listened to Ace.
Number one rule of the intergalactic explorer, Doctor. If you hear somebody talking about good vibes and letting it all hang out, run a mile.
We didn't.
That's beside the point.
What happens in there?
In where?
In the ring, during the talent contest.
Something pretty nasty.
Next contestant ready, please.
Oh, here, Nord.
What?
Remember our agreement?
Eh? Oh, yeah, course.
Well, heads, heads or tails?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Captain holds out his clenched fists to Nord.

Dialogue.Line: Tails.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Captain slaps a coin onto his left fist.

Dialogue.Line: Heads.
So?
You're on next.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Nord grabs the Captain by the throat.

Dialogue.Line: I ain't going on next!
But we all agreed, didn't we, Mags?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Mags leaps on Nord's back and he lets go of the Captain.

Dialogue.Line: Good girl.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The clown enters.

Dialogue.Line: He's next, I believe.
Get him ready.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Two robot clowns fetch Nord.

Dialogue.Line: You were lucky, Captain.
Not really. I got a whole set of these silly little nick-nacks from some bug-eyed monster when I was on the planet Leophantos.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Two heads on one and two tails on the other.

Dialogue.Line: Like I said, Doctor. Every man for himself here.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The clown gives the Doctor three juggling clubs before he leaves with Nord.

Dialogue.Line: What am I supposed to do with these?
Practise juggling, I suppose. Your chances of survival in the ring are better, of course, if you keep them entertained.
Why, do they let you out again?
No, but you last longer.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor drops the clubs.
Whizzkid pedals up to the stilt-walker.

Dialogue.Line: All right?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: They wave at each other.
Ace is eavesdropping.

Dialogue.Line: Just think of all those tickets we've sold. Does that make you feel good? It wasn't always like this, was it. Not before we came to this dreadful place. We used to have fun. We were free spirits then.
We are now.
You think so? It feels more like we're part of a machine.
Look, we're not leaving, if that's what you mean.
We must!
You keep saying that, but you haven't gone, have you?
I tried, but

Listen, just as long as they keep on coming, and they will, no doubt of that, we are a success. Don't you understand? An intergalactic success. Now, the others, they couldn't take the pace, that's all. Bellboy, Deadbeat, Flowerchild, the rest. Don't you understand? They wanted to live in the past, the old lazy way. Not us. We'll make the Psychic Circus known everywhere.
Known for what?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The clown enters.

Dialogue.Line: Well?
That new pair worry me. The girl that escaped had one of Flowerchild's earrings.
Have they found the girl?
Not yet, but she can't have gone far. I'll search for her myself.
Yeah, you do that. Make sure you find her.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Ringmaster leaves.

Dialogue.Line: And Bellboy?
Let's hope he's learned his lesson, shall we? We'd better get him back to work. Bellboy made them all. Bellboy can repair them.
But will he ever be able to

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Ace touches a kite, which starts chiming. She knocks it over trying to shut it up and runs round the ticket office with the clowns in pursuit. Then Whizzkid comes in.

Dialogue.Line: Hello. This is the Psychic Circus, isn't it?
Yes, that's right.
Oh great! I've come halfway across the southern nebula to be here. I want to enter the talent contest. I know all about the Psychic Circus, you see. In fact, I'm your greatest fan.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Ace runs through the tented corridors until she enters a room where Bellboy is tied to a workbench.
Nord has been dressed in a strongman's leopard skin costume over his biker leathers.

Dialogue.Line: I'll show you. Easy. Easy!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The clowns take Nord out.

Dialogue.Line: It frightens you, doesn't it, Mags?
Oh, he'll be fine. Just like the other one was.
You saw what happened in there?
So?
Aren't you going to tell me about it?
See for yourself!
Don't bother Mags, Doctor, will you? You have to be careful with these rare specimens.
What do you mean?
You'll see.
Look, I'm trying to help you, but you're not making it very easy. Can't you at least tell me what

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Heavy footsteps outside.

Dialogue.Line: Great. Don't tell them, will you?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Ace hides behind the workbench and the clown enters. Bellboy recoils in fear.

Dialogue.Line: Learnt your lesson, eh, Bellboy? No more running away now. Good, because I've got some important repair work for you to do. The Conductor's been damaged. That girl must be somewhere.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Nord enters and does a good snatch and grab on a barbell. The family lift score cards - three 9s.

Dialogue.Line: A man of might is Nord. And now he'll go for broke by making all you laugh with his most favourite joke.
Eh? What, do a gag? Like a joke? Yeah, well, I'm coming down like on the Psychic Circus tonight on the way

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The scorecards are three zeros and the canned crowd boos.
The zapping noise can be heard and the strobing lights seen.

Dialogue.Line: Is this what you saw before?
Not exactly, but just as bad.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: There is a peal of thunder then a big flash, and smoke. The Ringmaster picks up a piece of charred leather from the middle of the ring to canned applause.

Dialogue.Line: Would you let something like that happen to you?
Would you?

It must be awfully exciting working for the Psychic Circus, Morgana. Particularly when you did your tour of the Boreatic Wastes. I think that most of your admirers would agree with me that that was one of your finest ever gigs. Well, in so far as you can tell from the posters
Would you like to be getting along inside?
You mean I can go in, just like that?
Yes. Go right now, please.
Oh wow!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor is practising his juggling with Mags.

Dialogue.Line: Mags.
What?
It's not going to work. I remember when I was on the baleful plains of Grolon, I
I don't care.
Ready?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Mags and the Doctor go to the cage door, where a pair robot clowns stand guard.

Dialogue.Line: I believe I'm on first.
No, I'm ahead of you.
No, you're not.
No, I am.
I insist on going out first.
Oh no, you don't.
Oh yes, I do!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Ringmaster enters.

Dialogue.Line: Now listen folks, we have a great new act. He's a real find, there's no doubt that's a fact. He'll entertain you, he'll make you stare, and our great new act is seated over there!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The spotlight finds Whizzkid.

Dialogue.Line: I hope he's better than the last one.
Couldn't be much worse.
Mum, Mum.
Shut up and eat your popcorn.
Look, I insist in going on first.
I told you, I am.
I am!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The clowns come over and the door slides up. The Doctor and Mags knock them out with the clubs.

Dialogue.Line: Join the club. Captain?
No thanks, old boy. I'll sit this one out. Goodbye, Mags.
Bye, Captain.
That'll do. Take it back to the bus.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Ace watches them leave. Deadbeat comes up behind her and won't let her past. Then the clown grabs her.

Dialogue.Line: Let me entertain you.
Well, I have to say it's a real thrill for me to be here at the Psychic Circus. I've collected all your posters, you know.
Have you now?
From all your venues. And also I've got some very interesting

Dialogue.Stage Direction: They see the clowns lying on the floor. The Captain smiles at the Ringmaster.

Dialogue.Line: Oh Doctor, oh Doctor, have no fear. Calling the Doctor. There's no escape. Repeat, there is no escape.
Won't they take no for an answer?
No. Oh, we should have made straight away for the open air, I suppose.
Look.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: They are by a large stone structure.

Dialogue.Line: How extraordinary. They're just like the stones in the Big Top. Fascinating. I wonder how long they've been here?
Maybe they were always here.
That thought had occurred to me. Let's investigate.
Oh! Can you see it?
See what?
That moon sign.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Mags turns away from the twin crescents in the stone lintel.

Dialogue.Line: The moon? Why does it frighten you? Tell me.
Don't ask. Just lets get out of here.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The clown manhandles Ace inside a sturdy trailer with Psychic Circus etched into the glass in the door.

Dialogue.Line: Pasty face.
Don't like clowns, eh? After some time in here, you'll tell me what I want to know.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The clown leaves, locking the door. Ace is trapped with a load of apparently deactivated robot clowns.

Dialogue.Line: Is any one there? Come on, you don't scare me.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A hand grabs at her arm. She gets away from it, but behind her back another robot starts to move.

Dialogue.Line: Why did you bring them here?
Survival of the fittest, old girl. Don't tell me you never came across that on the planet Vulpana?
But we were on the edge of discovering the secret of the Psychic Circus. Doesn't that interest you at all?
Frankly, no, old chap. Anyway, what's going on seems pretty clear to me. Anybody dumb enough to get into the ring gets killed.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Two robots are slowly advancing on Ace as she struggles with the door knob.

Dialogue.Line: Just because I said I don't like them, doesn't mean I'm scared of clowns, okay? Got that, tinhead? I said, got that, tinhead?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Ace backs up against the far wall, then grabs at one robots hand. The whole arm comes off. She's just about to use it as a club when the robots stagger and stop. She pushes one over. Bellboy is cowering in a corner.

Dialogue.Line: Oh, I'm sorry. That shouldn't have happened. I must have fallen asleep.
We've met before. Don't you remember me?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor and Mags are escorted out. Mags turns to see that the stone over the moon symbol has moved, and now the crescent is nearly full. Mags snarls. The clowns all turn their attention to her.

Dialogue.Line: Mags, now please. Not now. Not yet!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor takes the opportunity to run.

Dialogue.Line: I don't think much of this, Father.
Nothing's happening, is it.
Not that I can see.
Mum, Mum!
What is it?
I'm bored.
There's no point in going on, dear. We're all bored. Something has to happen soon.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Captain and Mags are under escort.

Dialogue.Line: After all I've done for you, the Doctor gets away and you and I are going back to the guardroom.
You were lucky.

Yes, I suppose you're right. I'm still in one piece. You would have given us the full works. Still, the old team of Mags and the Captain stuck together as usual. As a matter of fact, it reminded me of that time of Fagiros, when the Architrave of Batgeld was showing me his early collection of Ganglion pottery

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor takes another look at the kites with their eye marking.

Dialogue.Line: Of course, of course.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: He steps inside the little caravan cum ticket office and gazed into Morgana's crystal ball. It turns red and that same eye stares back at him.

Dialogue.Line: Things are beginning to get out of control quicker than I expected.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: He hides under the counter as Deadbeat comes out of the Big Top. He goes to the crystal ball, clutching a large pendant with the same eye design.

Dialogue.Line: No, no.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: And runs away again. The Doctor moves to follow him, pausing at a poster.

Dialogue.Line: Fun for all the family? I don't know how they've got the nerve.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Bellboy takes Flowerchild's earring from Ace.

Dialogue.Line: Oh, my Flowerchild. They murdered you with a robot I made.
You're sure that's what happened?
There can be no doubt. Every robot, every clown in the circus I made and maintained, for this. And even now they won't let me die. They need me.
You mean you're the only one who knows how?
Each of us, each of us in the circus, we all had one circus skill we learned, and mine was this.
This control unit's brill.
Have it.
Really?
Yes. It controls that, and the full scale version I made.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A model of the robot Ace and Mags dug out of the sand. Ace makes it move its arm.

Dialogue.Line: Careful. That activates the laser eyes. It was to have been my masterpiece, but like everything else it was, it was abused and went wrong. We had such high ideals when we started. We shared everything and we enjoyed making people happy. If we had a problem we'd all just sit round and talk it through. Oh, we were so happy. At least, I think we were.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Deadbeat stops.

Dialogue.Line: Hello, Deadbeat. Fancy meeting you here. Small world, isn't it. It frightened you to see that eye, didn't it. It means the powers behind it are on the move again. Something happened to you here. You haven't always been like this. Did you try and find something out? Were you punished? Can you understand anything I'm saying? Well, there's one thing I do know, Deadbeat. You're not going to give me away to the others. Are you?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Deadbeat shakes his head.

Dialogue.Line: I wouldn't. I wouldn't.
Lead on, Deadbeat.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The family have finished their packets of crisps and are now holding chocolate ice lollies.

Dialogue.Line: You know, I could get quite cross about this.
Oh wow, is that Captain Cook, the famous intergalactic explorer and
Quiet. Where's the Doctor?
He gave us the slip.
He did what?
He gave us the slip. A similar thing happened to me in the Bay of Paranoia on Golobus.
I don't care what happened on Golobus.
Your loss, old boy. Anyway, it was all her fault.
Hang on a minute.
I imagine you'll have to put her into the ring next as some sort of punishment.
No.
Oh, found someone else, have you?
Yes.
Really. May I enquire who?
You.
Excuse me, but you are Captain Cook the famous intergalactic explorer. I've got maps at home showing all your journeys and a piece of one of your old shoes I bought in a souvenir shop
Will you leave me alone!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Morgana is staring into her crystal ball when the Ringmaster enters.

Dialogue.Line: Hey, hey, Morgana, Morgana. Hey, baby, you were long gone.
Look. It's here, now.
What do you mean?
What we found. What we serve. It'll always be here now, waiting for us to
Don't come with all that now.
Don't pretend you don't see it!
Look, I've got an empty circus tent in there right now. I don't want to talk about anything else.
Well, send in another act.
I will, baby, just as soon as I can.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The clown enters.

Dialogue.Line: The Doctor's escaped. Your idiot of a Captain failed us.
All right, send him in the ring.
It's arranged already, but I'm more worried about the Doctor. He's dangerous.
Well, let's go find him, then.
I'll go find him. You get back in the ring.
Hey, just a minute, man
Quiet, both of you! Look, it's showing him to us.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The crystal ball shows the Doctor following Deadbeat through the curtained backstage passageways.

Dialogue.Line: But he's with Deadbeat.
Then he must be stopped at once.

Oh, the kites she made, beautiful kites, every colour of the rainbow. All different shapes and sizes. And they use them to watch us and trap us and keep us here. So they destroyed her work and then they destroyed her.
It'll be all right, Bellboy. I'll get you out of here.
Why should I want to get out of here? It's gone. The fun, freedom of being what you want to be, all of it. Don't you understand?
Yes. Look, I'm sorry. We can't stay here forever, can we. I've got to find the Doctor for a start.
They took everything that was bright and good about what we had, and buried it where it will never be found again.
I don't understand. Who's they?
The ones who run the circus. The ones you've met. There wasn't just them, there was some. There was.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Bellboy pins Flowerchild's earring back onto Ace's jacket.

Dialogue.Line: Flowerchild and, and Peacepipe, and Juniperberry, and, and Deadbeat. No, he wasn't Deadbeat then, he was er, he was, he was. It's gone.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The clown leads four robots backstage. A shadow appears at the glass door and rattles the door knob.

Dialogue.Line: They're coming to take me to the ring, Bellboy. They may need you to repair the robots, but I'm just trouble. Making a bit of a mess of opening the door, aren't they? It can't be that difficult.
Oh, maybe, maybe it is the end after all.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The door opens, and Deadbeat and the Doctor enter.

Dialogue.Line: Doctor!
Deadbeat, I take it all back. (to Ace) You're absolutely right. Clowns can be creepy.
Sift the dreams in your mind.
King.
You'll be amazed
Kingpin! That was your name. Kingpin.
So you've always been interested in the Psychic Circus, have you? Sit down.
Oh yes, of course.
Ah.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Captain pours the tea.

Dialogue.Line: I've never been able to visit it before now, but I've got all sorts of souvenirs. Copies of all the advertising satellites that have ever been sent out. All the posters. I had a long correspondence with one of the founder members too, soon after it started. Although I never got to see the early days, I know it's not as good as it used to be but I'm still terribly interested.
Two minutes, Captain.
Thank you, Ringmaster. No doubt you dream of having the ultimate Psychic Circus experience as soon as possible.
Sorry?
You ache for the moment when you can do your own act within that sawdust covered magic circle.
Oh, yes, of course. I mean, there's no real danger, is there, really.
Only for those without resource or imagination or panache. I'm sure you have all those qualities.
Well, I really don't know.
Come, come, dear boy, don't be so absurdly modest.
Don't listen to him.
But this is one of my heroes, Captain Cook, the intergalactic space explorer.
Exactly. And shall I tell you what I'm prepared to do for you as a special favour?
What?
Postpone my brief moment of glory in the ring so that you may enjoy the unforgettable experience before me, far beyond the bouncing Upas trees of Boromeo or the singing squids of Anagonia.
Are you sure you can bear to let me go in first?
It is a sacrifice I am prepared to make.
The dreams. Sift the dreams. When the mind's divided the body screams.
Yes, some of it's coming back now. Not all of it. He was Kingpin. He was the one who persuaded us to come here. There was something he wanted, something he knew about. And we all trusted him, and
Something went wrong?
Yes. Something went very wrong. It's this place, you see. It does things to you.
And a friendly hippy circus was turned into a trap for killing people.
Yes. Even our own kind. That was after Kingpin was no longer Kingpin. Something went. Something went with him and
And the well?
What well?
You don't know anything about a well with an eye peering out from inside?
No.
An eye, like the one of Flowerchild's, like the ones on the kites.
No, not any more.
Don't look in the well. The eye gives you promises of heaven or hell.
He's off, he's gone. I knew people like him in Perivale.
Listen, Ace.
What to?
The answers. You know what happened, don't you, Deadbeat?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The clowns tumble into the ring.

Dialogue.Line: At last.
Now welcome, folks. I'm sure you'd like to know we've got a brand new act for your circus show. Now welcome please with all the warmth you can, the Psychic Circus' greatest fan!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Whizzkid enters to canned applause.

Dialogue.Line: This is the most exciting day of my life. My dream come true. I'm standing in the ring of the Psychic Circus.
You've sent that poor boy out to his death.
Nonsense. He may be a great success.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The family give him a score of three zeros.

Dialogue.Line: So it just goes to show you never can be certain.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Whizzkid screams, and the thunder and lightning crash.

Dialogue.Line: As I said, survival of the fittest.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Ringmaster picks up the bent and cracked remains of Whizzkid's spectacles to wild canned applause.

Dialogue.Line: Deadbeat, if we take you to the well, can you show us what it did?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Deadbeat nods.

Dialogue.Line: How do you know it's not all a con, Professor?
Well, he brought me here to you and Bellboy. He must have done that for a purpose.
Not if your brains are that scrambled.
Ah, now there's something there, Ace. I saw it when he looked into the crystal ball.
You're just an aging hippy, Professor.
There might be something in that, yes. Anyway, we'd better be going. Bellboy?
Er, no.
Come on, Bellboy.
No, I think the chief clown will be here after you and I could delay him for a while. I'd be pleased to make myself useful.
But Bellboy?
You still don't understand, do you. Everything I loved has gone. There's no point in living on to do work I hate.
So be it, then, Bellboy. Come on, Deadbeat. Or should I call you Kingpin? We've got work to do.
Bye now, Bellboy. All the best. Oh, and er, thanks for this.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The robot remote control.

Dialogue.Line: Bye, Ace. Goodbye, Kingpin, Doctor.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Morgana speaks to the eye in the crystal ball.

Dialogue.Line: The acts will keep on coming now, we promise, and no one will ever go near the bus again. Those who remain are your servants to do with as you wish. No, I never wanted to resist your power.
Where are they?
I don't know. I don't care. It's all destroyed, you know that. Oh, you were a wonderful clown once. Funny, inventive.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The clown slaps Bellboy.

Dialogue.Line: Quiet.
I'm not helping you any more, you see.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Bellboy uses a clown remote control to activate all those in the workshop.

Dialogue.Line: Take care, Bellboy.
Come on. Come on. Deal with me as you dealt with Flowerchild.
You're crazy.
Come on. Come on! Come on!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Deadbeat gets to the well with the eye first.

Dialogue.Line: No. I can't do it.
Come on, Kingpin. Nearly there. Hold on, please.
Now, Kingpin, show us what you did when you first saw the eye.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Deadbeat holds out the amulet and shuts his eyes. Then he collapses.

Dialogue.Line: Great stuff, Kingpin.
He must have used that medallion to summon the powers that lurk here.
And it did this to him.
Yes.
I wish I had some Nitro Nine to lob down there. Hang about. The mirror here, it's an eye.
Yes, that eye seems to plague us everywhere, only with the eyeball removed by someone or something.
And hidden.
In the bus.
Where Flowerchild died trying to get it.
Shall be free. We shall be free. We shall be free. We shall be free.
Calm down, Mags. There'll be some more contestants along soon. We're doing very well.
That poor boy.
Us or him, Mags. And before you get too high and mighty, remember where you'd be without me. Dead with a bullet in you on the planet Vulpana. A silver bullet.
I know that, Captain, but you didn't do it for me, you did it for yourself. I only wish I knew what you were after.
All in good time, Mags. All in good time.
It's so tantalising. I'm so close to understanding it all and yet so far.
So we'll have to get hold of that other bit of mirror.
Exactly. Now, you take Kingpin back to the bus and find it, but be careful.
Hang on a bit, Professor. This is all going a bit too fast for me. I'll fetch it, no problem, but what about you?
I'm going back to the ring.
Are you off your head?
The Psychic Circus needs acts. If they've got me then perhaps they won't worry about you two for the moment.
Sometimes I think it's you that's crazy, not Deadbeat here.
Anybody remotely interesting is mad in someway or another.
I don't know where they find these acts, do you, Mother?
Never seem to get any better, do they, Father?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor walks past a robot clown.

Dialogue.Line: I believe you've been looking for me. I'm wanted backstage.
Greetings, Captain Cook. Mags. You will be pleased to hear that the greatest act in the galaxy has returned to the fold.
Jolly good show, Doctor.
But Doctor, I helped you to escape.
I know, Mags, and I haven't wasted the time you bought me. And I have returned with an idea. I suggest that this time we all three work together.
Meaning?
Up to now all the people in the cage have been played off against each other, and of course some people are cleverer at preserving themselves than others.
Luck of the draw, old boy.
Not entirely. What I'm proposing is that we all three go into the ring. Three for one and one for three. That should throw a very big hammer into the works.
I'm with you, Doctor. And so's he.
Now just a moment, Mags.
Aren't you, Captain.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Ace helps Deadbeat crawl out from under the tent and run away from the circus.

Dialogue.Line: Captain!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: He throws his whip over to the Captain, who uses it.

Dialogue.Line: I hate it when this happens. She can't control herself, of course, and like all her kind she'll destroy whatever comes in her path. Which, I'm afraid, in this case has to be you.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The family give this act a score of three nines.

Dialogue.Line: This circus is only the half of it, you see, old chap. These hippy fellows weren't quite so dumb as they look. Did you come here just for the fun of it? Well, some of them did, but they're all dead.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The little girl's eyes glow green.
A pair of robot clowns deliver the repaired bus conductor.

Dialogue.Line: Could I see your tickets, please.
We experienced explorers know all about making the most of our discoveries. The powers here can be harnessed by those intrepid enough to grasp the opportunities. Myself, for instance.
Those powers destroyed Deadbeat.
Yes, but he was like you, Doctor, none too bright in the old self- interest stakes.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor dodges Mags' attack, and the Captain uses the whip to keep her away from himself.

Dialogue.Line: Stop it, Mags. This werewolf is extremely dangerous.
You're meddling with things you don't understand.
No, Doctor, you are. Once you're out of the way, I shall make my deal with the powers that be, whoever they may be.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The clown and Morgana are using the crystal ball.

Dialogue.Line: She's taking Deadbeat to the bus.
In that case, they're also taken care of.
I remember once visiting the gold mines of Katakiki
Captain Cook!
What?
You're not only a scoundrel and a meddling fool, but you're also a crushing bore.
I'm afraid you've really done it this time, old boy. Mags!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: In true Errol Flynn style, the Doctor climbs some scaffolding then swings across the ring on a rope to get away from Mags.

Dialogue.Line: Search, search, search for the truth. Search it out, search it now.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Ace is searching around the drivers seat until she finds a switch behind a pedal that opens a compartment containing cash box.

Dialogue.Line: This must be it.
Search it now.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Ace bangs on the window from the inside.

Dialogue.Line: Kingpin, I've found it!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Conductor looks out from his curtained off compartment at the back of the bus.
The Doctor is up on a catwalk around the ring and so is Mags.

Dialogue.Line: Mags! Mags! Do you hear me? Mags!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Captain keeps cracking the whip as the clown and Morgana enter. Mags reaches the Doctor and goes for his throat.

Dialogue.Line: Mags, when you're like this, this isn't in your nature, you have to destroy everything that crosses your path. I don't believe that. Mags!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor uses the rope to swing back across the ring to where the family are sitting. They all stand up and their eyes glow green. A high pitched sound makes the Doctor tumble backwards down the seating and into the ring, where Mags is waiting.

Dialogue.Line: Mags! Mags! Wait, wait. I need your mercy, but you don't have to kill.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Mags turns to the Captain.

Dialogue.Line: Come on, Mags. You can trust me. You know that, don't you? Once he's out of the way we can split the proceeds. Do it for me, do it for your old pal the Captain. You know you'll enjoy it. I order you to. I order you to!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Mags leaps on the Captain.

Dialogue.Line: No, Mags! No!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Ace comes out of the bus with the cash box.

Dialogue.Line: Search, search, search for the truth. Search, search, search
You've got to try and help me, Kingpin. I can't get it open.
Search, search, search for the truth.
What I'd give for my chemistry set now.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Conductor comes out of the bus behind Ace's back.

Dialogue.Line: Search, search, search for the truth.
Come on, Kingpin. Do try and concentrate a bit.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Deadbeat laughs as the Conductor grabs Ace's head and pulls her up. She drops the box.

Dialogue.Line: Tickets, please. Tickets, please.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Conductor's foot steps on the box, and it opens.

Dialogue.Line: Tickets, please.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Ace struggles to get the robot remote control out of her jacket pocket, and the Conductor knocks it out of her hand.

Dialogue.Line: Tickets, please.
Kingpin! Please!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: While Ace bruises her elbow trying to hit the Conductor, Deadbeat takes a small blue eye from the box and puts it on his medallion.

Dialogue.Line: Kingpin, do something!
I remember now! It's beneath the cap.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Conductor throws Deadbeat to the ground.

Dialogue.Line: What?
Knock its cap off!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Ace does.

Dialogue.Line: Now what?
Bellboy put a button that said Request Stop. Press it!
What?
Press the button!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Ace struggles to reach the Conductor's head, and hits it. It lets her go and starts flailing around. There is a high-pitched noise.

Dialogue.Line: Now stand back.
What?
Stand back, quick.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Ace crawls away then goes back for the robot remote by its feet.

Dialogue.Line: No! Get away! Quick!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: KaBOOM goes the bus Conductor.

Dialogue.Line: Now we're getting somewhere. You really are Kingpin, aren't you.
Yes, thankfully. But no one's safe until we get this (the medallion) back to the Doctor.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Mags has returned to normal and the Captain is carried out of the ring on a stretcher, pith helmet on his chest.

Dialogue.Line: Come on, Mags. We've got to run away, now.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The clown and Morgana try to block their path, but Mags snarls at them and they move aside quickly.

Dialogue.Line: We want more.
Mags!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: They dive through the slit in the cloth that Ace made with Flowerchild's earring all that time ago.

Dialogue.Line: Er, another act's coming soon, folks. You can believe me.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The little girl speaks with a very deep voice.

Dialogue.Line: Another act now.
We want more.
(deep voice) We need more.
You haven't played fair with me.
Listen, we've done everything we're supposed to do, right?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The clown sneaks to the entrance.

Dialogue.Line: I had my doubts, but I came through in the end.
There are going to be other visitors.
We need more.
You have no one left to give.
Except yourselves.
No!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The clowns wheel on a pair of laundry baskets.

Dialogue.Line: Please, more acts are on the way, I promise you.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The clowns push the Ringmaster and Morgana into the baskets. There is a high- pitched whine then the baskets are opened up again. Only the Ringmaster's top hat remains.

Dialogue.Line: Something dreadful's happening in the ring. Things are getting out of control quicker than I expected.
Calling the Doctor. Calling the Doctor.
Nothing will satisfy them but my presence.
I'm coming back in there with you.
No. You must run and get Ace and Deadbeat.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Mags runs off.

Dialogue.Line: I must prepare for my entrance. Never keep your audience waiting.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The clowns chase Mags outside, then they head for the hearse. Down in the well, the eye gets bigger.
A wind starts to blow.

Dialogue.Line: I'm coming. Open a pathway for me. Once small step for mankind, one great leap, or words to that effect.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor pulls apart the canvas entrance to the Circus and steps into a kaleidoscope world of noise and colour. He fights his way through with gritted teeth to -
A semi-circular sand floor, grey stone walls with one grilled doorway, and three large figures sitting on thrones looking down.

Dialogue.Line: And here we all are at last. I'm surprised you brought me here. It must be very difficult for you, trying to exist concurrently in two different time spaces. I know the problem myself. No wonder those memorial stones looked familiar. The Gods of Ragnarok, I presume.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The stallholder has hitched the stall to her horse and is manoeuvring it to turn round. Mags jumps over the hitch and keeps running.

Dialogue.Line: Don't you frighten my horse like that, you hippie weirdo.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The hearse has to stop and sound its horn.

Dialogue.Line: Shut up, circus riff-raff. You don't own this planet, you know.

How many people have you destroyed, I wonder, before Kingpin was lured down here. Poor Kingpin. That's what you like, isn't it. Taking someone with a touch of individuality and imagination, and wearing them down to nothingness in your service.
Enough.
You have said enough.
Enough? I've hardly started. I have fought the Gods of Ragnarok all through time.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor looks at his watch.

Dialogue.Line: You are in our true time space now, Doctor. There is no appeal beyond its confines to any other.
Don't tell me what you want me to do. Let me guess. Now let me see. You want me to
Entertain us.
Entertain us.
Or die. So long as you entertain us, you may live.
When you no longer entertain us, you die.
Predictable as ever, Gods of Ragnarok. As I think it's been said before, or was it after? Anyway, you ain't seen nothin' yet.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor leans and swings round at a remarkable angle.
Ace and Deadbeat meet Mags.

Dialogue.Line: Hey, Mags! Where's the Doctor?
Back at the circus.
So you're on your own now?
Not exactly. Look.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Here comes the hearse. Mags sees the completed medallion.

Dialogue.Line: That's what they're after.
Oh, I might have guessed.
So how do we get it back to the Doctor? Oh, dumbo! Not you two, me. I've got an idea. Come on!
Wrong way!
Not for this. Come on, Kingpin!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor has a table in front of him, with a large pan and its cover.

Dialogue.Line: Thank you very much, ladies and gentlemen, for that overwhelming reception. And now, I would like to begin like life, at the beginning. But how did life begin? Was it with a chicken or was it with
What?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor produces an egg from his mouth and puts it in the pan. Then a second one which goes into his hand and disappears.

Dialogue.Line: Don't try our patience.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: She throws a lightning bolt near the Doctor.

Dialogue.Line: Don't play games.
You're not interested in beginnings. You're only interested in endings.
Oh no, not that thing again. Come on.
Dumbo. Bellboy's robot.
Dead right, Kingpin.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The three hide behind the robot as the hearse pulls up and the clowns run out.

Dialogue.Line: Bellboy's greatest mistake. What a place to choose. You may have the Eye again, Deadbeat, but you won't use it. You know that. You're not strong enough! You weren't before.
At least I tried. You just gave in.
Yes, and I shall get my reward. Last chance, Deadbeat. We really believed in all that talk of peace and love
This thing had better work, or I'll kick its head in.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Ace jabs at the remote control. After a few moments, the robot lasers one of the robot clowns, then the other three. Finally it kills the clown himself and keeps firing as Ace keeps pushing buttons. Then it goes quiet.

Dialogue.Line: For a moment I thought you weren't going to be able to make it stop.
Funny you should say that.
He used to be a great clown.
I've never liked clowns.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: To the strains of Narcissus being played on a violin, the Doctor produces a length of rope and ties the ends together.

Dialogue.Line: What, no complaints? No arguments? No thunderbolts?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The rope falls into a single length with the knot still in it.

Dialogue.Line: No, Doctor.
We're not concerned that you're playing for time.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor has untied the knot and is now fastening the two pieces of rope together. Then he stands on a loose end and pulls it into a single piece of rope again.

Dialogue.Line: We have a saying.
Let me guess. Give yourself enough rope and you hang yourself.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor looks at his watch again.

Dialogue.Line: Kingpin.
I only hope we make it in time. The Doctor's stronger than I ever was, but even he can't hold out against them forever.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Mags, Ace and Deadbeat get into the hearse.

Dialogue.Line: He'll have a good stab at it, though.
You are nearing the end, Doctor.
A piece of rope has two ends, Father Ragnarok.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor coils the rope into the pan. Then he produces a long candle from his handkerchief and lights it with a flame apparently from his palm. He puts the lit candle to the pan with bursts into flames, briefly puts the cover over it to extinguish them and removes a snake from it. Mum throws a thunderbolt.

Dialogue.Line: Feel the rain, Doctor.
Feel the chill in your bones.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor turns around and the snake turns into his umbrella. He puts it up just before the downpour starts.
The wind is still howling. Ace stops to look at the crystal ball.

Dialogue.Line: Ace, quick! Come on!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor is attempting to escape from a strait-jacket whilst hanging by his ankles from a rope.

Dialogue.Line: Doctor.
Yes?
You are trifling with us.
Really? I thought I was entertaining you.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: He gets the strait-jacket off.

Dialogue.Line: You are on the brink of destruction, Doctor. We want something bigger, something better.
Do you now?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Deadbeat, Mags and Ace run into the deserted ring.

Dialogue.Line: The Doctor must be here somewhere.
Well, he may already be in the Dark Circus with the Gods. If so, there's only one way we can reach him.
The stone chamber.
And the medallion?
Yeah. We must be careful. They're bound to sense its presence.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor is back on his feet.

Dialogue.Line: Do I have your full attention?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: He checks his wrist watch.

Dialogue.Line: You do realise that they'll try anything to stop us?
Yes. Let's go.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Behind the advertising boards, the Captain sits up from the stretcher and puts on his pith helmet.

Dialogue.Line: The climax of my act, Gods of Ragnarok, requires something you do not possess in great abundance. That is, imagination. And it starts with a piece of metal. This piece of metal once belonged to a sword, and that sword belonged to a gladiator.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor throws the piece of metal into the air, where it transforms into a gladius, and then a long sword drops into his hand.

Dialogue.Line: And that gladiator fought and died in this ring to entertain you.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Deadbeat stops at the well.

Dialogue.Line: Go for it, Kingpin.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: But the Eye is staring back up at him. He backs away.

Dialogue.Line: Kingpin, please.
Well, one of us had better try.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Deadbeat holds out the medallion and shuts his eyes. The Captain hits him in the kidneys and catches the medallion as he falls.

Dialogue.Line: Perhaps I might relieve you of that.
Captain, I thought you were dead.
I am, my dear. I am.
I have fed you enough, Gods of Ragnarok, and you found what I have to offer indigestible. So I have taken myself off the menu. La comedia e finita.
We command you.
You cannot stop.
I already have.
Then you will die.
Probably not. It's all a matter of timing, don't you know.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor points the sword to the ground.

Dialogue.Line: Oi, sarcophagus face!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Captain turns and Mags kicks the medallion out of his hand and into the well. It lands on the sword and the Doctor uses it to reflect the Gods' laser bolts back at them. The Eye in the well grows.

Dialogue.Line: Quick.
You know, when I was on the planet Periboea, I met someone who walks around when he was already dead. I must say, as an experience I'd say it was very overrated.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Captain falls into the well.

Dialogue.Line: Look. Get down!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The crystal ball explodes. In the arena, the Gods stop firing laser bolts at the Doctor and slump in their seats. The walls crack and buckle. The Doctor throws the sword and medallion at them then raises his hat as the whole place falls apart. The Big Top crumples as the arena disintegrates. The Doctor walks out and doesn't flinch as an explosion occurs just behind him.
A huge red pillar of smoke climbs to the sky. The Stallholder speaks to her horse.

Dialogue.Line: It's what I've always said. No consideration for those of us that live here.
Enjoying the show, Ace?
Yeah. It was your show all along, wasn't it?
The Captain really is finished now, isn't he?
Yes. But you're just about to start.
Doctor, I've been thinking.
What better way for a circus to begin than with a wonderful new act.
Yeah, weird and wonderful. Nice one, Professor. You'll knock them dead.
That's just what I'm afraid of. What if I can't control it?
Oh, you can, Mags. You already have.
What about it, Doctor? You and Ace. Join Kingpin's new circus and travel the galaxy with us.
Thank you, Kingpin, but I'm afraid we've got other galaxies to travel. And besides, I find circuses a little sinister.
